description: Cucumber is a widely cultivated creeping vine plant of the gourd family, Cucurbitaceae. It is known for its crisp, cool texture and is commonly used in salads, pickles, and beverages.

soil.type: Well-drained, sandy loam soil rich in organic matter

climate.watering: Water regularly at the base of the plant. Avoid overhead watering to prevent diseases. Ensure soil is well-drained.

symptoms: Dark, sunken lesions on the fruit and leaves.
Yellowing around the lesions, often leading to leaf blight.

background.cause: Fungal pathogen *Colletotrichum orbiculare* that thrives in warm, wet conditions.
background.spread_by: Rain, wind, contaminated seeds, and infected plant debris.

cure: Remove and destroy infected plants and fruit to reduce the spread of the fungus.
Apply fungicides such as Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb at the first sign of infection.
Ensure good airflow by spacing plants adequately and avoiding overhead watering.
Apply fungicides regularly during rainy periods to prevent new infections.
diseases.fertilizers: Use balanced fertilizers with a focus on potassium to improve plant resistance.
prevention: Practice crop rotation and avoid planting cucumbers in the same soil for consecutive years.
Use disease-free seeds and resistant varieties.
Improve garden hygiene by removing plant debris and weeds that can harbor the fungus.
Water early in the day and avoid wetting the foliage.

symptoms: Wilting of the plant, starting with leaves turning yellow and limp.
Darkening of the vascular tissue in stems.

background.cause: Bacterial infection caused by *Erwinia tracheiphila*, spread by cucumber beetles.
background.spread_by: Cucumber beetles, contaminated tools, and infected plant debris.

cure: There is no chemical cure for bacterial wilt once plants are infected.
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately to prevent the spread of the bacteria.
Control cucumber beetles by using insecticides or organic control methods like neem oil or insecticidal soap.
Use row covers to prevent cucumber beetles from accessing the plants.
diseases.fertilizers: Apply balanced fertilizers to support plant growth and boost resistance to diseases.
prevention: Control cucumber beetles by introducing natural predators such as ladybugs.
Practice crop rotation and avoid planting cucumbers in the same area year after year.
Use resistant cucumber varieties if available.

symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on the fruit's underside, leading to softening and rotting.
Foul smell emanating from the rotting fruit.
Dehydrated plants with a decline in fruit quality.

background.cause: Fungal pathogen *Pythium spp.*, which thrives in waterlogged conditions.
background.spread_by: Excessive moisture, poor drainage, and contaminated tools.

cure: Remove and dispose of infected fruit immediately to prevent the spread of the fungus.
Ensure proper drainage in the growing area and avoid overwatering.
Apply fungicides like Metalaxyl to manage the infection.
Avoid overhead watering and water at the base of the plant.
diseases.fertilizers: Use low-nitrogen fertilizers to avoid excessive soft tissue growth, which is more susceptible to infection.
prevention: Improve soil drainage and avoid waterlogging around the plants.
Avoid planting cucumbers in overly wet areas.
Use drip irrigation to keep foliage dry and reduce disease spread.

symptoms: Yellow angular lesions on the upper side of the leaves, often surrounded by a purple margin.
Downy, grayish mold growth on the undersides of leaves.
Rapid defoliation and reduced fruit production.

background.cause: Fungal-like pathogen *Pseudoperonospora cubensis*, which thrives in cool, moist conditions.
background.spread_by: Wind, rain, and infected plant debris.

cure: Apply fungicides like Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb as soon as symptoms appear.
Prune affected leaves and remove them from the area to reduce the spread of the disease.
Ensure proper airflow and spacing between plants to reduce humidity.
Avoid overhead watering to keep the foliage dry.
diseases.fertilizers: Use balanced fertilizers to ensure plant health and boost resistance to diseases.
prevention: Water early in the morning to allow leaves to dry before nightfall.
Use resistant cucumber varieties where available.
Improve garden hygiene by removing infected leaves and debris.

symptoms: Dark, sunken lesions on stems, leaves, and fruit.
Exudation of gummy, sticky sap from infected areas.
Wilting and death of infected plants.

background.cause: Fungal pathogen *Didymella bryoniae*, which thrives in warm, moist conditions.
background.spread_by: Wind, rain, and infected plant debris.

cure: Remove and destroy infected plants and fruit to prevent further spread.
Apply fungicides such as Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb at the first sign of infection.
Prune affected stems and dispose of them properly.
Ensure good airflow and avoid overcrowding of plants.
diseases.fertilizers: Use balanced fertilizers with a focus on potassium to improve plant resistance.
prevention: Practice crop rotation and avoid planting cucumbers in the same soil for consecutive years.
Use disease-free seeds and resistant varieties.
Improve garden hygiene by removing plant debris and weeds that can harbor the fungus.

symptoms: Water-soaked, mushy lesions on the fruit.
Premature fruit drop and poor yield.

background.cause: Fungal pathogen *Pythium spp.*, which thrives in wet, poorly-drained conditions.
background.spread_by: Water splashing, soil-borne pathogens, and contaminated tools.

cure: Remove and destroy infected fruit immediately to prevent the spread of the fungus.
Ensure proper drainage in the growing area and avoid overwatering.
Apply fungicides such as Metalaxyl to control the infection.
Water plants at the base to avoid wetting the foliage.
diseases.fertilizers: Use well-balanced fertilizers to promote healthy fruit development and reduce susceptibility to disease.
prevention: Avoid waterlogging and improve drainage in the growing area.
Use drip irrigation to avoid overhead watering.
Space plants adequately to allow for good airflow and reduce humidity around the plant.

preventive_practices: Use disease-free seeds and resistant plant varieties.
Practice crop rotation to prevent soil-borne diseases.
Ensure good air circulation around plants to reduce humidity.
Use drip irrigation to keep foliage dry and reduce the spread of waterborne diseases.
Mulch around plants to conserve moisture and reduce soil splashing.
Remove and destroy infected plant debris promptly to prevent further spread.
Regularly monitor plants for signs of pests and diseases.
